On 21/12/2007, edu_kumar <sarat.beesa@...> wrote:
>  My problem is that i've a really huge method,which calls several small
>  methods ( methods so small, they're just getters for member
>  variables), If i have to unit test this method, i've to make sure all
>  the small methods that it subsequently invoke, work as they're
>  expected. But all my member variables get initialized seperately in a
>  different method which is of no relation with the BIG method I wanted
>  to test in the first place.
....
>  Can I test my method without worrying about the initialization of my
>  object's data, by mocking the results of all my getter methods ?
>  I tried using Jmock for creating mocks in my test case, but it fails
>  because the mock object only knows what exactly I wanted to mock but
>  nothing more than that. All my application logic is present in
>  'MyClass' object not in its mock.
>
>  How can I achieve this using Jmock ?

This is not what jMock is designed for.  Mock Objects are used to test
how the object under test affects its environment by sending commands
to other objects.  They are not for testing the implementation details
of what goes on *inside* the object under test.

In your description of what you're trying to test, you described
trying to test a method.  That to me is a smell.  It would be better
to think about testing the *object*, not individual methods.

To write a test for an object you need to answer questions like: What
does the object do? What messages do I send the object to make it
perform the behaviour I am testing? What resources does it need
perform that behaviour?  What other objects does it need to talk to?
Are those objects internal implementation details, or peers of the
object under test?

If you can answer those questions, you can easily work out which
objects should be mocked out, and which should be hidden within the
object under test.

The other smell is that the method is huge, and has complicated
dependencies on initialisation methods.  It sounds as if the class
needs to be divided into smaller, simpler objects that can be more
easily unit tested and that define proper constructors.

To do that without an extensive suite of unit tests, I would first
write some integration or system tests that cover the behaviour of the
class. I would then pull behaviour out of the big class into smaller
classes, writing those smaller classes test-first.  The system tests
would give me some confidence that my refactoring had not broken
everything.  Writing the new classes test-first would drive out a less
coupled design that would be easier to maintain in the future.

--Nat
